holdings.name: VHS, Audio Cassette, Text; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: Design for irrigation: reconstructure of the home farm. Pt 2
results.brief_description: Describes a plan for more efficient irrigation of an old property. The chief problem is poorly designed and maintained supply and distribution ditches. In some areas, trees are small and deformed through lack of water - in others flooding is so bad that neighbours complain of seepage. Suggests immediate plan requiring cleaning and modification of supply and drainage channels. The long term plan put forward suggests the use of concrete channels and underground pipelines, which would result in perfect water distribution and in this case, room for more trees in place of open channels.

results.title: Design for irrigation. [Parts 1 & 2]
results.brief_description: Shows that a proper plan of irrigation is essential when planting new orchads. The example in the film is a new block of slightly sloping land which is to be planted with fruit trees. A model of the block shows the contours, and the method of ploughing, irrigation and planing which should be carried out in relation to the contour lines.

results.title: Desert people
results.creator_credit: William L. Claiborne and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description: Shows the importance of water to desert people. Compares the Tuaregs, nomadic people constantly in search of water, with the Hajputs, who are cultivators, running water through an ancient irrigation system by camel power and natural flow. This film has no English dialogue, the images speak for themselves. However, you can hear the Desert people in their native tongue.

results.title: Desert parks: the how to travel video
results.creator_credit: Outback Explorers Video Productions and Westprint Maps
results.brief_description: Crossing the Simpson Desert is one of the world’s greatest motoring adventures. The Desert National Parks of South Australia also include Innamincka Reserve and Lake Eyre. You can get there via the Birdsville, Oodnadatta and Strezlecki Tracks. But it’s rugged and isolated terrain. What if you break down? Where can you get fuel? Is it safe for the family? How much water to take? Where are the tracks? What spare parts to take? Where to get Park permits? This programme answers all these questions and more. Trip preparation, how to travel in safety, basic four-wheel drive techniques are all covered as the spectacular scenic highlights are shown and as you hear some colourful history and speak to the people that live and work there.

results.title: Desert ecology
results.creator_credit: Walter H Berlet and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: Deals with plants and animals living in a hot desert climate. Discusses the adaptations which enable them to withstand the long dry periods. Also shows daily living patterns of animals which enable them to survive in the great heat. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Describing an incident
results.brief_description: A group of students describe an incident. In the first instance a poor description is given - a girl trying to describe how a friend’s father nearly missed a train, wanders off into irrelevant detail and fails to capture interest. Another girl, describing the same incident, creates interest with an ordered and well-presented account.

results.title: Descendant of Genghiz Khan = Potomok Chingis-Khana
results.brief_description: Better known under the title “Storm over Asia”, this exotic film is a remarkable drama of British Imperial intrigue in Mongolia in the civil war days of 1920. Valeri Inkijinov plays a young Mongolian trapper ostracised from his village after he is cheated out of a valuable fox fur by a European trader. Becoming a Soviet partisan, the trapper is thrust into prominence when it is learned that he is descended from Genghis Khan. The occupying English army (identified as the White Russian army in foreign prints of the film) puts the trapper in charge of a puppet Mongolian government. By film’s end, however, the “puppet” has cut the strings in a spectacular fashion. In Russian with English subtitles.

results.title: Derwent runs down to the sea
results.creator_credit: Don Anderson, Linda Taylor, Mobil Oil Australia and Tasfilm Productions
results.brief_description: Shows a canoe trip along the River Derwent from its source in the highlands at Lake St Clair in Tasmania. Explains the river’s importance in supplying water for agriculture, transport and power.
